name: Purchased goods and services
Emissions calculation methodology: i. Methodology: Danone has chosen a product life cycle analysis (LCA) approach in compliance with GHG Protocol principles to design an internal assessment tool providing the product carbon footprint of its activities worldwide on Scope 3 (Raw ingredients, packaging, co-manufacturing, transportation of raw materials from suppliers gates to Danone plants gates, distribution of finished products, use of sold products, end of life treatment of sold products) – excluding capital goods, business travel, employees commuting, up and downstream leased assets, franchises and investments (assessed during the tool’s peer review which concluded that each of these stages represent less than 1% of the total emissions). ii. Data: volumes of actual consumptions (based on Danone’s ERP) are multiplied by emission factors coming from several databases toobtain the corresponding absolute emissions. Databases used emanate from professional associations (Plastics Europe, FEFCO, FEVE), lifecycle inventory databases (Ecoinvent, Carbon Trust) and certifications carried out by our suppliers on their own specific products. For emissions coming from milk, accounting for 41% if emissions at group level, Danone has developed together with the French Livestock Institute an in- house tool (Milk tool) calculating emissions by liter of milk based on a large number of parameters (feeding composition, yield per cow, manure management type, crops cultivation, etc.). Emission factors for dairy ingredients cover transformation processes and are based on specific data for key parameters (energy intensity ratios) of countries where processes take place. Other raw materials cover non-dairy ingredients like sugar, starch, fruits preparations and related emissions are cradle-to-gate. For fruit preparations, emissions cover fruit cultivation, first transformation process, storage of the prepared fruit, second transformation process, as well as transportation between these steps. For packaging, emissions include production of all packaging types, i.e. primary (consumer unit packaging), secondary (selling unit packaging) and tertiary (tray, crate, pallet). For co-making products, produced outside of Danone’s manufacturing sites with the Danone brand, the company is responsible for their distribution to customers. Related emissions are calculated based on primary data from co-manufacturers.

name: Capital goods
explanation: Danone has carried out an assessment of these emissions in 2008. Results indicate that this category represents less than 1% in the overall life cycle analysis of a single product. Therefore, Danone applied cut-off rules which are the current practice in the LCA state of the art approach.

name: Fuel-and-energy-related activities
Emissions calculation methodology: i. Methodology: this category covers upstream emissions of purchased fuels (i.e. extraction, production and transportation of fuels consumed), upstream emissions of purchased electricity, steam, heating and cooling (i.e. extraction, production and transportation of fuels consumed in the generation of electricity, steam, heating and cooling consumed by the company), as well as transmission and distribution losses (i.e. generation of electricity, steam, heating, and cooling that is consumed in a transmission and distribution system). ii. Data: actual consumptions are multiplied by emission factors coming from several databases to obtain the corresponding absolute emissions. Databases used include Ecoinvent for upstream fuel, and DEFRA for scope 3 electricity.

name: Upstream transportation and distribution
Emissions calculation methodology: i. Methodology: this category covers emissions linked to transportation of raw and packaging materials from suppliers to manufacturing sites and semi-finished products from co-manufacturers to Danone sites. ii. Data: calculations are based on distances from suppliers to Danone sites, transport type (road, rail, maritime, air transport), average fuel consumption, maximum truck capacity, filling and empty return rates (for road transport for the three latest parameters). The sources of emissions factors used are Carbon Trust and Ecoinvent databases.

name: Waste generated in operations
Emissions calculation methodology: i. Methodology: these emissions relate to ingredients losses at plant level, as well as finished products losses occurring at the transport stage, after manufacturing processes. Losses faced at retailer level are currently not collected in the tool. ii. Data: losses (in percentage) are multiplied either by the total life cycle footprint of the product withoutlosses (for finished goods losses and some ingredients losses, leading in the latter case to a conservative value) or by the difference between actual and theoretical volumes of ingredients and the corresponding emission factor. Main sources for emissions factors are Ecoinvent and databases from professional associations.

name: Business travel
explanation: Danone has carried out an assessment of these emissions in 2008. Results indicate that this type of emissions represents less than 1% in the overall life cycle analysis of a single product. Therefore, Danone applied cut-off rules which are the current practice in the LCA state of the art approach.

name: Employee commuting
explanation: Danone has carried out an assessment of these emissions in 2008. Results indicate that this type of emissions represents less than 1% in the overall life cycle analysis of a single product. Therefore, Danone applied cut-off rules which are the current practice in the LCA state of the art approach.

name: Upstream leased assets
explanation: This category is not relevant to Danone's business model and therefore has been excluded.

name: Downstream transportation and distribution
Emissions calculation methodology: i. Methodology: this category covers emissions relating to transport of Danone’s products between company’s plants, between company’s plants and Danone’s distribution centers and from company’s plants or distribution centers to customers. ii. Data: calculations are based on distances (between Danone’s sites or between Danone and customers sites), transport type (road, rail, maritime, air transport), average fuel consumption, maximum truck capacity, filling and empty return rates, percentage of Danone products in trucks (applying to road transport for the four latest parameters). The sources of emissions factors used are Carbon Trust, Ecoinvent databases, or primary data from transport providers (e.g. for the evian brand, part of maritime transport providers have their emission factors certified).

name: Processing of sold products
explanation: This category is not relevant to Danone's business model and therefore has been excluded.

name: Use of sold products
Emissions calculation methodology: i. Methodology: this category includes emissions relating to the storage of finished products at retailers and end customers locations. ii. Data: at retailers’ level, emissions are calculated based on quantity of net product per pallet, average data from a major retailer (energy intensity ratios at retail distribution centers and shops) and product and country of sale key parameters (product’s size, percentage of refrigerated storage at retail distribution centers and shops, electricity and natural gas emission factors of country where the product is sold). At end consumers’ level, emissions are obtained based on quantity of net product per pallet, consumer habits from survey (percentage of refrigerated storage at home fridges, duration of storage in home fridges, occupation ratio in home fridges, average electricity consumption for home fridge) and electricity emission factors specific to the country where products are sold. Energy intensity ratios come from Carbon Trust, electricity and natural gas emission factors from IEA and IPCC databases.

name: End of life treatment of sold products
Emissions calculation methodology: i. Methodology: this category includes emissions linked to the treatment and collection of waste generated on site (losses of packaging on site), in the shops (retail) and at end consumers’ level (domestic). All packaging type, i.e. primary (consumer unit packaging), secondary (selling unit packaging) and tertiary (tray, crate, pallet) are taken into account in the end of life. ii. Data: calculations are based on amount of packaging waste, breakdown (%) by treatment type (landfilling, incineration with and without energy recovery, recycling) per packaging type and country, and emission factors per treatment and packaging types per country. Percentages of end destinations per packaging type and country come mostly from professional associations (e.g. FEVE, Plastics Europe), emissions factors come from the Wizard LCA tool and national databases.

name: Downstream leased assets
explanation: Emissions from downstream warehouses which are not owned or under operational control of Danone are reported in the category downstream transportation and distribution.

name: Franchises
explanation: This category is not relevant to Danone's business model and therefore has been excluded.

name: Investments
explanation: The consolidation scope consists of all Danone subsidiaries that are fully consolidated for the preparation of the consolidated financial statements, in other words the subsidiaries in which Danone holds, directly or indirectly, exclusive control.

name: Consumption of purchased or acquired electricity
Consumption of purchased or acquired heat
Consumption of purchased or acquired steam
Consumption of purchased or acquired cooling
Consumption of self-generated non- fuel renewable energy
